title: Piston - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Seat, Battery and Fuel Tank Removal T*1
Use a marker pen or similar to mark the front of the piston crown for assembly identification.
Remove and discard the gudgeon pin circlip from one side of the piston.
If a circlip is dropped into the crankcase, it must be recovered before the crankshaft is rotated. Failure to do so will result in serious engine damage.
Remove the gudgeon pin by pushing the pin through the piston and connecting rod toward the side from which the circlip was removed.
Never force the gudgeon pin through the piston. This may cause damage to the piston which can also damage the cylinder when assembled.
If the gudgeon pin is tight in the piston, check the piston for a witness mark caused by the circlip. Carefully remove the mark to allow the pin to be removed.
Remove and discard the remaining circlip from the piston.

The rings may be removed using a proprietary piston ring expander tool. Or, if a tool is not available, carefully spread the ring opening using thumb pressure then push up on the opposite side of the ring to remove it from the piston.
If the piston rings are to be reused, note the orientation of the oil control rings prior to removal.

search: Piston - Removal
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Perform the following operations:
Seat - Removal
Battery - Removal
Fuel Tank - Removal
Cylinder - Removal
Use a marker pen or similar to mark the front of the piston crown for assembly identification.
Remove and discard the gudgeon pin circlip from one side of the piston.
If a circlip is dropped into the crankcase, it must be recovered before the crankshaft is rotated. Failure to do so will result in serious engine damage.
Removing the Gudgeon Pin Circlip
Remove the gudgeon pin by pushing the pin through the piston and connecting rod toward the side from which the circlip was removed.
Never force the gudgeon pin through the piston. This may cause damage to the piston which can also damage the cylinder when assembled.
If the gudgeon pin is tight in the piston, check the piston for a witness mark caused by the circlip. Carefully remove the mark to allow the pin to be removed.
Remove and discard the remaining circlip from the piston.

The rings may be removed using a proprietary piston ring expander tool. Or, if a tool is not available, carefully spread the ring opening using thumb pressure then push up on the opposite side of the ring to remove it from the piston.
Remove the piston rings.
If the piston rings are to be reused, note the orientation of the oil control rings prior to removal.
